;;穿着戏服的狂欢者在二丁目区摆姿势拍照。周末夜晚尤其热闹，人们纷纷涌上街头——在同性婚姻不合法的国家，这里是 LGBTQ 人群的避风港。照片：法新社;
;

;Melvin Muranaka 长期以来一直想在东京新宿二丁目 LGBTQ 区开设一家酒吧，在那里他第一次感受到作为一名同性恋者可以自由地做自己，随着流行病他认为他的机会来了。

;

;“我有一个非常强烈的印象，我躲藏起来，但当我来到二丁目时，印象是每个人都在喝酒，玩得很开心，就像他们一样29 岁的 Muranaka 拥有日本和菲律宾血统，他说。

;

;“这表明我也可以真正做我自己，这让我感到惊讶，也让我感动，”他说。

;

;

;但是村中在二丁目开设自己的酒吧的计划遇到了障碍——人们也想在该地区开设新酒吧，兴趣高涨，随后出现了房产短缺，尽管该地区的建筑老化，未来前景广阔威胁有些可能会被拆除。

;
;;
;;二丁目区盛装参加聚会的人。二丁目由大约 400 家主要是小酒吧组成，分布在大约五个街区，通常被认为是世界上同性恋酒吧最密集的地方。照片：法新社;
;
;

;二丁目由大约 400 家主要是小酒吧组成，分布在大约五个街区，通常被认为是世界上同性恋酒吧最密集的地方.

;

;周末的夜晚尤其热闹，人们纷纷涌上街头——在同性婚姻不合法的国家里，这是 LGBTQ 人群的避风港，一些同性恋酒吧经理甚至还没有完全出柜。

;

;今年 2 月，日本首相岸田文雄 (Fumio Kishida) 的一名高级助手表示，如果允许同性婚姻，人们将会逃离日本，而且他不想与 LGBTQ 夫妇住在一起 - 不过他的言论引发了公愤，他被解雇了。

;

;在远离东京的地区，情况可能更加困难，那里保守的社会态度更为普遍。

;
;
;

; “二丁目很特别，它是 LGBTQ 人群聚集的地方，”在二丁目工作的家族第三代房地产经纪人 Takamitsu Futamura 说道。随着新地铁线的开通，二丁目至今仍坚守着自己的特色。政府补贴和低管理费用，再加上房东的租金折扣，意味着在大流行期间几乎没有地方失败。

;

;但即使是二村也很难解释想要在该地区开办新企业的人数激增的原因，而现在，可用房产短缺。

;

;“在大流行期间，人们的想法发生了变化，他们中的许多人经历了困难时期，因此他们可能认为是时候实现在这里拥有自己的房子的梦想了，”他说。

;

;二丁目的许多酒吧通常被称为“盒子”，只能容纳 10 到 20 名顾客，而且通常是几十年来的常客。

;
;;
;;东京二丁目区的一家酒吧。二丁目的许多酒吧通常被称为“包厢”，只能容纳 10 到 20 名顾客，而且通常是几十年来的常客。图片来源：法新社;
;
;

;长期以来，女同性恋酒吧数量众多，但二丁目现在可能不再以男性为主导，而且更加多元化。

;

;“女性、女同性恋者和跨性别者变得越来越引人注目，”研究该地区的文化人类学家砂川英树说道。

;

;“这是人们向往并聚集的地方，”他说。 “二丁目在日本仍然具有象征意义。”

;

;但是，容纳许多此类酒吧的建筑物（通常每层有几家酒吧）正在老化，漏水等问题日益增多。

;

;尽管目前的房东可能会与相同的租户进行重建，但二村表示，一旦他们的孩子继承了遗产，就不能保证他们会有兴趣举办相同类型的企业，这引发了对该地区长期未来的疑问。

;

;他指出附近一座正在兴建的建筑可能会成为一家长期住宿酒店，作为事情可能发生变化的例子。

;

;日本首相因反 LGBT 言论而解雇助手后，他的核心圈子受到了审查

;

;尽管地平线上可能有乌云密布，但九月二村仍有 20 至 30 人等待二丁目房产上市。许多人以前曾在同性恋酒吧工作过，年龄从 20 多岁到 50 多岁不等，其中一个人用的是上一份工作的退休金。

;

;虽然 LGBTQ 酒吧群正在东京其他地方开业，但大多数潜在租户坚称位于二丁目内的正式房产。即使穿过一条与另一个区域形成边界的街道也太过分了。

;

;“他们可以对所有事情都持开放态度。如果你经营一家同性恋酒吧，那真的只有二丁目，”二村说。 “大多数来的人都觉得，如果不是二丁目，那就不好了。”

;
;;
;;Ni 的狂欢者-丁目地区。尽管 LGBTQ 酒吧群正在东京其他地方开业，但大多数潜在租户坚持在二丁目内拥有正式的房产。照片：法新社;
;
;

;Muranaka多年来在二丁目酒吧混合白天工作和周末轮班。因疫情而搁置了自己的梦想后，他最终决定开自己的店。

;

;一年来频繁拜访二村地产经纪公司终于得到了回报，经过简单的装修后，他于9月开设了“AXL”。 .

;

;这家大约有 20 个座位的酒吧距离该地区的主要街道不远，以 L 形柜台为中心，就像二丁目的许多酒吧一样。

;

;这里有卡拉 OK 屏幕和一个酒吧。 ”有点可怕，”村中说道，并指出年轻顾客是该地区未来的关键——一批酒吧正在举办特殊活动，例如最近的婚介之夜。

;

;“他们还没有他们想知道这里是什么样子。我们想传达一种印象，即任何人都可以随意来玩。”

;香港人 Mary Lai* 花费了 45,000 港元（5,755 美元）进行美容治疗，其中包括在眼睛下方注射填充剂和非手术整容手术。

;

;那是三年前的事了。她对结果很满意，直到今年五月，她的脸颊上开始出现硬块。

;

;她的脸颊变得大小不等，左侧明显更肿。

;

;40岁时尚零售商回到知名医疗美容连锁店进行注射，但该连锁店否认承担责任，并给她开了类固醇。

;

;2 因在香港美容服务连锁店无证行医而被捕

;

;赖咨询了几位专家，最后一位整形外科医生告诉她“忍受肿块”，因为切除肿块的手术可能会让她的脸留下疤痕。

;

;“我花了几个月的时间在我无法接受并告诉其他人我的痛苦之前，”黎说，她在几个月后一直戴着口罩，需要咨询。

;

;总共，她花费了超过 6 万港元用于检查、咨询和治疗。

;

;最近，香港基本上不受监管的医疗美容行业再次成为人们关注的焦点，19 人在荔枝角一家连锁店接受脂肪注射注射后出现细菌感染。

;

;11月初，四人因涉嫌进行无证医疗行为而被捕。

;
;;
;;玛丽·赖说开始出现硬块在接受眼下填充剂注射和非手术整容手术三年后，她的脸颊上出现了这种现象。图片：讲义;
;
;

;十一月下旬的另一宗案件中，两名女子在旺角另一家美容院因同一罪行被捕。

;< p>;据称，他们在过去一年中为 700 多名顾客进行了注射，包括注射平滑皱纹的肉毒杆菌，并开了类固醇药物以尽量减少副作用。

;

;行业参与者、医生和其他人士呼吁采取更多措施监测和监管医疗美容行业的综合框架承认，实施更严格的控制将具有挑战性。

;

;他们一致认为，迫切需要提高公众对寻求此类美容治疗时如何保持安全的认识。

;

; >;

;整形外科医生刘兆基医生建议黎接受她拙劣的美容治疗，他说她的案例只是冰山一角。

;

;他说他看到了大约十几个人。每年都有患者因医疗美容手术而出现各种不良结果。

;
;
;

;“监管医疗美容行业非常困难，”他说。 “谁来划清界限？”

;

;就是要确保市场上的医美产品质量好、来源可信、使用得当，而提供此类服务的人也必须接受。

;

;例如，肉毒杆菌注射已获得美国食品和药物管理局批准用于特定治疗，但医生经常将其用于其他美容目的。

;

;就黎女士而言，她的异常状况的原因仍不清楚，因为她不知道使用了什么产品、质量或来源。

;

;刘表示，为业内人士制定明确的标准并不容易，因为“他们没有治疗疾病”。

;
;;
;;整形外科医生 Peter Pang 博士担心“医学美容”一词给人一种错误的感觉对客户的安全。相片：杨新;
;
;

;没有规管法例或定义

;

;香港并无针对医疗美容服务的具体法例。该术语没有官方定义，但通常被理解为改善客户外貌的美容治疗。

;

;其中包括抚平皱纹、减少多余脂肪和去除多余毛发的手术。

;

; >;

;全市约有6,000家美容院，但尚不清楚有多少家提供医疗美容服务。

;

;具体规则规范了场所、设备、药品、销售行为和执业医师的职业行为，过去十年中，大多是在治疗不当导致多人死亡后引入的。

;

;不满意的客户的投诉从未停止过。

;

;消费者委员会已多次就潜在风险发出警告在收到数百起有关质量和销售行为的投诉后，医疗美容服务陷入陷阱。

;
;;
;;Shirley Chan 说她的右侧出现了一个肿块接受肉毒杆菌注射后，下巴变得不对称。图片：讲义;
;
;

;今年前9个月，共收到202起投诉，大部分与激光或强脉冲光治疗有关，其次是侵入性治疗。

;

;2016年，监管机构敦促当局明确“医疗美容”的定义并加强监管，使该行业的监管有法律依据，有明确的许可框架、具体的操作规范和从业人员的能力要求。< ”安全性，让人们认为他们接受的手术符合医疗标准——专业、清洁和安全。但真的是这样吗？”

;
;
;

;他曾在本市以及韩国、台湾和泰国等地治疗过对医疗美容手术结果不满意的患者。

;
;
;

; >;

;庞说，他们的挫败感往往源于管理不当的期望，因为他们没有意识到潜在的副作用，包括一些会消退的临时症状。

;

;使用未经注册的药物会产生更严重的问题错误的剂量，或者在最坏的情况下，非医生的个人未经许可在美容院、酒店房间、家里甚至公共厕所进行手术。

;

;其中一些案例具有挑战性

;

;“行业格局发生了很大变化，”庞说。 “在过去的十年里，政府在经历了致命的错误之后，取得了一些进展……主要是在规范医生方面。”

;

;需要的不仅仅是医疗执照

;

;2013 年，卫生当局列出了四种程序——注射、表皮下皮肤的机械或化学去角质、高压氧疗法和牙齿漂白——需要由注册医生或牙医进行。

;

;大约有 400 名医生提供美容治疗，其中大部分是

;

;对美容医学特别感兴趣的全科医生林梅医生表示，美容医学并未被认可为医学专业。

;

; >;

;;
;;全科医生林梅医生表示，美容医学不被视为专业。摄影：新杨;
;
;

;因此医生必须自行到香港或海外接受培训，其中一些是获医务委员会认可的，包括某些文凭或硕士学位临床皮肤病学，但没有美容医学资格被视为“可引用资格”。

;

;包括医疗器械和美容产品制造商在内的组织也提供在职培训、奖学金、讲习班和学术活动研讨会。

;

;“培训机会很多，但结构不明确，”全科医生说。 “没有考试、临床培训或研究论文的要求，因为美容医学不是一个专业。”

;

;香港医学美容协会创会会长、整形外科医生林竹君医生表示从长远来看，这个城市需要一个更全面的培训框架。

;

;她说，许多资格没有得到官方认可，培训质量也没有保障，许多医生并没有完全从事这个行业，而是在周末去美容院打工。

;

;但整形外科医生指出，许多医疗美容失误都是由于无证执业、非医生在非临床环境下进行注射造成的。

;

;15名香港人因注射脂肪注射而感染，警方逮捕2人

;

;她说，更紧迫的任务是加强公众教育，确保居民意识到侵入性治疗应该总是由注册医生使用授权经销商或制造商的设备来完成。

;

;她说，人们甚至不知道如何验证用于此类手术的产品的真实性。例如，有些产品有一个可刮开的二维码，链接到显示产品来源的网页。

;

;“医生应该在客户面前打开盒子，向他们展示这是正品”。她说。

;

;她补充说，如果产品必须在该城市注册会更好。

;

;;
;;Khua Kling 的传统泰国菜“pla tu”曼谷的 Pak Sod 餐厅。照片：Aidan Jones;
;

;

;

;在“丰盛湾”，泰国最受欢迎的鱼失踪了。向西约 200 公里处，湄公河 (Mae Klong) 著名的鱼贩已转向印度尼西亚来解决短缺问题，因为海洋科学家警告说，普拉图的库存可能已接近崩溃的边缘。

;

;富含蛋白质的迷你鱼-曾经盛产于泰国湾的鲭鱼，如今正在消失，那些依靠鲭鱼获得收入和营养的人担心，这种肉质丰富、价格实惠的主食可能很快就会从他们的盘子里被抢走。

;

;短身鲭鱼的苦难已经酝酿了数十年；这是由气候变化、过度捕捞和全球对泰国海鲜日益增长的需求共同造成的。

;

;泰国是世界第六大鱼类和海鲜出口国，其国内市场似乎无法满足。

;

;泰国是世界第六大鱼类和海鲜出口国。 >;

;但是，随着海水温度上升和极端天气模式使洋流发生颠倒，海洋生态系统的压力也在增加，导致以浮游生物为食的高原人口急剧下降。

;

;气候变化的“邪恶”双胞胎正在吞噬东南亚的海鲜

;

;泰国渔民表示，他们现在的年捕捞量仅为 30 年前的三分之二，这对作为中心的海洋的更广泛健康敲响了警钟食物链的支柱开始动摇。

;

;科学家称，在生存斗争中，鱼类变得越来越小，繁殖也越来越早。

;

;“它们正在努力适应环境朱拉隆功大学海洋科学系助理教授 Jes Kettratad 告诉《亚洲周刊》。 “如果你再进一步推动，他们可能做不到，那就是股票崩盘的时候。”

;

;这是一条正在萎缩的鱼的故事，这个国家已经开始依赖以及拯救这个物种的时间已经所剩无几了。

;

;

;

;从泰国东海岸春武里府的一座小山上俯瞰一个海湾，海湾上布满了商业码头，散布着集装箱阿莫萨克·潘亚查罗恩斯里 (Amornsak Panyacharoensri) 回忆起那些冒着黑烟的船只，当时的情况截然不同。

;

;“当我还是个孩子的时候，大海充满了生机。我们以前只提着装满石蜡的防风灯走进大海，就这样捕捉海洋生物。”这位和蔼可亲的第三代渔民、春武里府沿海钓鱼协会会长说道。

;

;大蓝蟹阿莫萨克回忆道，石斑鱼和鲻鱼被光所吸引，一把就能捞到，因为奥乌多姆（Ao ​​Udom，意为丰盛湾）小村庄以其优质而丰富的鱼类和海鲜而闻名。

;

;但那是那时。

;
;;
;;泰国 Ao Udom 渔村被工业挤出。照片：Aidan Jones;
;
;

;“现在，曾经美丽、视野开阔的大海已成为工业基地，”他解释说，大型拖网渔船在离岸几公里处作业带走了大部分好的渔获，而靠近海岸的“周末渔民”则与当地人争夺其余的鱼。

;

;“对我们的鱼的需求来自各地，有国内的，也有全球的……[现在]春武里府是泰国大肆宣传的东部经济走廊的关键，这是一项耗资数十亿美元的基础设施计划，旨在将这个东南亚国家转变为物流和航空中心。

;

;新港口、航运加油点以及从电动汽车巨头到飞机零部件制造商等公司已经加入了已经遍布工业化东海岸大部分地区的炼油厂、管道和工厂。

;< div>;;
;;曼谷市场上出售的 Pla tu。照片：Aidan Jones;
;
;

; Sat, 09 Dec 2023 09:09:18 +0800 US-China’s ‘tense’ Pacific power play to persist after Australia-Papua New Guinea security pacthttps://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3244443/us-chinas-tense-pacific-power-play-persist-after-australia-papua-new-guinea-security-pact?utm_source=rss_feed

;

;Power tensions between the United States and China in the Pacific will continue to be “tense and dynamic” even as Australia and Papua New Guinea forge deeper relations through a newly signed historic security pact, according to analysts.

;

;On Thursday, the two Pacific neighbours closed a legally binding bilateral security agreement to work together on defence and policing, mirroring elements of recent agreements struck between China and the Solomon Islands.

;

;Australia is committing A$200 million (US$132 million) towards Papua New Guinea's national security priorities.

;

;A key US ally, Australia has been resetting relationships in the Pacific following the Solomon Islands' controversial security pact with China, but it does not mean that the regional power contest is over, said Patrick Kaiku, a political science fellow at the University of Papua New Guinea.

;

;所罗门群岛于去年4月首次与中国达成协议，该协议将允许中国警察或军事人员在太平洋国家提供社会秩序或救灾，而中国海军船也可以停靠补给和机组人员接送。 In July, the Solomon Islands firmed up an agreement to boost cooperation with China on law enforcement and security matters.

;

;Tuvalu gets climate win in new Australia pact, but it comes with a 'trade-off'

;

;Since Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese came into office last May, his government has signed a climate migration deal with Tuvalu last month and a defence agreement with East Timor last year. The previous Scott Morrison government was criticised for failing to preserve relations with Pacific nations.

;

;“The long game is still being played out, and although China's domestic economic problems will affect its economic and diplomatic footprint in the Pacific, China will remain an alternative partner of choice for Pacific Island states,” Kaiku said.

;

;While Australia, as a member of the “Pacific family”, has an upper hand when it comes to security deals, contests for power and influence in other areas including aid and trade would remain “tense and dynamic”, said Meg Keen, director of the Lowy Institute Pacific Islands Program.

;

;“Pacific island countries have been clear they want to have relations with Australia, US and China and will strongly protect their right to be friends to all,” she said.

;
;;
;;Chinese President Xi Jinping meets with Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare in Beijing on July 10. China has been stepping up its engagements with Pacific nations. Photo: Xinhua/Zhang Ling;
;
;

;“Australia is consolidating its position as the security partner of choice, but the Pacific welcomes China as a development and trade partner. China will remain a key player in the region for a long time to come.”

;

;Geopolitics in the region took a turn last year when the Solomon Islands signed its controversial policing pact with China. The move prompted US and Australian diplomats to step up engagements with the Solomon Islands before its Prime Minister Mannasseh Sogavare accused those countries critical of its deal with China of foreign intervention and disrespecting its sovereignty.

;

;Consequently, to relate better with Pacific nations such as PNG, Canberra had framed the language of the treaty with Port Moresby to appeal to their shared principles of democracy and rule of law between both sides, Kaiku said.

;

;Build now, pay later? Debt-ridden Fiji turns to China for port upgrades

;

;“This is a powerful narrative in countering China,” Kaiku said. “China's policing culture and its questionable illiberal and repressive practices are not viable in security cooperation in weak states such as the Solomon Islands or PNG.”

;

;Washington and Canberra could also learn from the lessons of the tensions that arose from the US-PNG maritime and defence deal signed in May, said former German ambassador to New Zealand and seven Pacific Island countries, Anne-Marie Schleich.

;

;“This agreement was heavily criticised in PNG and raised questions about PNG's sovereignty and its long-held 'friends to all, enemy to none' foreign policy principle,” said Schleich, who is also an adjunct Senior Fellow at the S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies.

;

;“After this political backlash back home, PNG Prime Minister James Marape needed to clarify the sovereignty issue with Australia, which held up the negotiations and signing of the [subsequent] Australia-PNG agreement.”

;
;;
;;US Secretary of State Antony Blinken (right) speaks during a meeting with Papua New Guinea Prime Minister James Marape (left) during the Apec summit in San Francisco on November 16. Photo: AFP;
;
;

;While the region continues to focus on the US and its allies in their competition with China, Pacific nations would look to leverage these power shifts to their advantage, Kaiku said.

;

;It is less so about how much which side would prevail but to what extent the needs of the Pacific nations can be met, he added.

;

;“We also must look at how Pacific Island states are adept in maximising their interests in this whole situation. This is not about Australia [and the US] being 'successful' [in reducing China's regional influence],” he said.

;

;He pointed to Deputy Prime Minister of Fiji Biman Prasad, who recently pressed Australia and New Zealand for visa-free arrangements with Pacific nations and for their skilled workers to work in Australia and New Zealand.

;

;“For us in the Pacific, the worst fears are that we will blindly walk into a conflict that we have no control over,” he said.

; Sat, 09 Dec 2023 08:20:02 +0800 More Vietnamese say goodbye to dead-end jobs to make big money as TikTok live streamershttps://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/3244381/more-vietnamese-say-goodbye-dead-end-jobs-make-big-money-tiktok-live-streamers?utm_source=rss_feed

;

;Vi Thi Anh spent half a decade doing monotonous low-paid work in industrial hubs near Vietnam's capital Hanoi, assembling mobile phones for global electronics companies including Samsung.

;

;Then she discovered she could earn vastly more hawking food products to thousands of followers as one of the country's growing cadre of TikTok live streamers.

;

;Communist Vietnam's supply of cheap labour has attracted some of the world's top companies, but climbing salary expectations have enticed many young people to leap into the exploding business of social commerce – whether to boost their incomes or to extricate themselves from dead-end jobs.

;

;Anh, 23, said she earned just US$400 per month in her “boring” factory job, barely enough to cover her rent and food, before she was laid off in 2021 thanks to falling orders from the West.

;

;She found another factory job, but soon “turned to full-time live streaming so I could earn more for my family,” Anh said, the thick rice noodles she sells online laid out behind her, drying in the sun.

;
;;
;;Vi Thi Anh shows off noodles at her workshop in Bac Giang province. Photo: AFP;
;
;

;On her TikTok channel, which has over 350,000 followers and 15 million likes, orders fly in for the US$4 noodle packs, made by her uncle.

;

;“This pack of noodles is so colourful, but completely safe and delicious,” Anh tells her audience, pointing to red, yellow and purple bundles.

;

;Between June and September this year, more than 118,000 people, mostly in the garment and footwear sector, lost their jobs in Vietnam, according to official figures.

;

;At her home in northern Bac Giang province, Anh said that like she did, workers fear “that if they are laid off, they have no way of earning a living”.

;

;Live streaming, she said, offers a way to ease that worry.

;

;Nearly 80 per cent of Vietnam's 100 million people have access to the internet, and according to a recent survey by the data agency Statista, a similarly high percentage of Gen Z use TikTok.

;

;Vietnam's youth opt for 'lying flat' amid crushing stress of economic boom

;

;“Farmers, workers and students can easily start their own channels,” said Nguyen Doan Ky, co-founder of the DC 3 Do agency, which offers social media and live streaming services.

;

;“Online selling used to be only for businesses or shop owners. Now it is an opportunity for everyone.”

;

;As in neighbouring China, where farmers are making big money on TikTok, e-commerce is booming in Vietnam, with sales growth averaging 30 per cent year over year for the last decade.

;

;Vietnam is one of the world's top 10 growth markets and turnover is expected to reach more than US$20 billion this year, according to the ministry of industry and trade.

;
;
;

;Coming from the country's rural and mountainous north, Luong Quang Dai never imagined he would become an influencer with 420,000 followers online.

;

;He earns 10 times as much as he did before live streaming thanks to his popularity on TikTok and Facebook, selling dried bananas, vermicelli noodles and a tea mix made in his neighbourhood.

;

;“We can save up to 100 million dong per month (US$4,000) and at the same time help create jobs and a stable income for relatives and friends,” the 33-year-old said from his farmhouse in the forests of Bac Kan province.

;

;In his youth, Dai spent two years trying to find a route out of the hard, spare life of a farmer, moving to the city in a familiar story of urban migration.

;

;In Vietnam, 'flexers' have US degrees, status, wealth. Others barely sleep

;

;But failing to earn enough for even basic necessities, he returned to his home in the countryside, where two-thirds of Vietnamese still live.

;

;In addition to farming, he began to post videos on social media of him and his wife feeding chickens and harvesting bamboo in the depths of the forest.

;

;The simplicity of the posts soon earned him an enormous following, and he began to sell his produce in huge quantities.

;

;“Social media has changed my life completely,” Dai said.

;

;Tran Thanh Nam, an education psychology expert, cautioned that although social commerce has become popular, TikTokers needed to keep updating their skill sets.

;
;;
;;Farmer Luong Quang Dai shoots a video of his wife cooking at his house in Bac Kan省。 Photo: AFP;
;
;

;“Businesses that take off in a short space of time … can also turn into failures quickly,” he said.

;

;But he understood the appeal, he added.

;

;“Becoming a worker in a factory or industrial zone is a way to use up all one's youth and health … and they lose a lot of other opportunities.”

;

;According to state media, on TikTok alone there were 30 training programmes on digital transformation that attracted thousands of learners in 2022.

;

;Among other blue-collar workers to have found an audience and a decent income is Loc Fuho – a former builder with 2.5 million followers who live-streams lessons in masonry and plastering.

;

;Dai is still happy to be a farmer, “but a digital one”, who has influence and a good income.

;

;“I expect nothing more,” Dai said.

; Sat, 09 Dec 2023 07:50:02 +0800 Europe reaches deal on world’s first comprehensive AI ruleshttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/europe/article/3244480/europe-reaches-deal-worlds-first-comprehensive-ai-rules?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.12.09 07:38;
;

;European Union negotiators clinched a deal on Friday on the world's first comprehensive artificial intelligence rules, paving the way for legal oversight of technology used in popular generative AI services like ChatGPT that has promised to transform everyday life and spurred warnings of existential dangers to humanity.

;

;Negotiators from the European Parliament and the bloc's 27 member countries overcame big differences on controversial points including generative AI and police use of facial recognition surveillance to sign a tentative political agreement for the Artificial Intelligence Act.

;

;“Deal!”午夜前夕，欧盟委员蒂埃里·布雷顿(Thierry Breton)发推文。 “The EU becomes the very first continent to set clear rules for the use of AI.”

;

;It came after marathon closed-door talks this week, with one session lasting 22 hours before a second round kicked off Friday morning.

;
;
;

;Officials provided scant details on what exactly will make it into the eventual law, which would not take effect until 2025 at the earliest. They were under the gun to secure a political victory for the flagship legislation but were expected to leave the door open to further talks to work out the fine print, likely to bring more back room lobbying.

;

;The EU took an early lead in the global race to draw up AI guardrails when it unveiled the first draft of its rule book in 2021. The recent boom in generative AI, however, sent European officials scrambling to update a proposal poised to serve as a blueprint for the world.

;

;The European Parliament will still need to vote on it early next year, but with the deal done that is a formality, Brando Benifei said late on Friday.

;

;“It's very very good,” he said by text after being asked if it included everything he wanted. “Obviously we had to accept some compromises but overall very good.”

;

;OpenAI applies for GPT-6, GPT-7 trademarks in China

;

;Generative AI systems like OpenAI's ChatGPT have exploded into the world's consciousness, dazzling users with the ability to produce humanlike text, photos and songs but raising fears about the risks the rapidly developing technology poses to jobs, privacy and copyright protection and even human life itself.

;

;Now, the US, UK, China and global coalitions like the Group of 7 major democracies have jumped in with their own proposals to regulate AI, though they are still catching up to Europe.

;

;Once the final version of the EU's AI Act is worked out, the text needs approval from the bloc's 705 lawmakers before they break up for EU-wide elections next year. That vote is expected to be a formality.

;

;The AI Act was originally designed to mitigate the dangers from specific AI functions based on their level of risk, from low to unacceptable. But lawmakers pushed to expand it to foundation models, the advanced systems that underpin general purpose AI services like ChatGPT and Google's Bard chatbot.

;
;
;

;Foundation models looked set to be one of the biggest sticking points for Europe. However, negotiators managed to reach a tentative compromise early in the talks, despite opposition led by France, which called instead for self-regulation to help home-grown European generative AI companies competing with big US rivals including OpenAI's backer, Microsoft.

;

;Also known as large language models, these systems are trained on vast troves of written works and images scraped off the internet. They give generative AI systems the ability to create something new unlike traditional AI, which processes data and completes tasks using predetermined rules.

;

;Under the deal, the most advanced foundation models that pose the biggest “systemic risks” will get extra scrutiny, including requirements to disclose more information such as how much computing power was used to train the systems.

;

;Researchers have warned that these powerful foundation models, built by a handful of big tech companies, could be used to supercharge online disinformation and manipulation, cyberattacks or creation of bioweapons.

;

;AI poses 'extinction' risk comparable to nuclear war, pandemics: experts

;

;Rights groups also caution that the lack of transparency about data used to train the models poses risks to daily life because they act as basic structures for software developers building AI-powered services.

;

;What became the thorniest topic was AI-powered facial recognition surveillance systems, and negotiators found a compromise after intensive bargaining.

;

;European lawmakers wanted a full ban on public use of facial scanning and other “remote biometric identification” systems because of privacy concerns while governments of member countries wanted exemptions so law enforcement could use them to tackle serious crimes like child sexual exploitation or terrorist attacks.
